You should really read the book Ella Minnow Pea by Mark Dunn. The story is written in letters between different characters, but eventually those characters aren't allowed to use certain letters (they would be arrested if they did, for example the first letter they weren't able to use was Z). This continues until there are only 5 usable letters left (L, M, N, O, and P). It's such a great book, I'd highly recommend it!

So to clarify a book written without the use of a letter is called a lipogram, a type of constrained writing. The entire idea of constrained writing was popularized by a french group from the mid  20th century called the Oulipo. George Perec's A Void is shown at the start and he was a founding member of the group. Italo Calvino is probably the most famous of the group and wrote tons of works with constraints.  One interesting one was one he wrote by doing a Tarot reading and making a story based on the cards he got.

I read an epistolary novel called "Ella Minnow Pea" in middle school and its one of my favorite books. It's set in a nation that worships these letters of the alphabet, and have all 26 nailed to a thing in the town square or something like that. The letters start falling off so the government starts banning those letters because they thought it was a sign from the gods essentially. People are required to report friends and neighbors who use the letter, and all mail is screened to look for it. People even have to change their names to fit within the new constraints. If you are caught three times, you're exiled.

The book is written as letters being sent back and forth between people in the town discussing their lives, the issues at hand, and other things, and as the book goes a long they lose more and more letters, and the author stops writing with them, until the only letters left are L M N O P. It's really incredible to read
